bullets.text: U.S. added 119,000 jobs in September; unemployment held at 4.4%. Mixed labor signals reduce odds of near-term rate cuts.
Fed likely to hold rates in December; Cleveland Fed’s Hammack says policy is 'barely restrictive'.
Goods sector softening: freight downturn and falling Chinese imports suggest a 'structural goods recession' despite services-led job growth.
Stocks reversed sharply as AI anxiety rose; tech leaders slid and SoftBank plunged, while Bitcoin hit its lowest since April.
Nvidia’s blowout results fueled bubble chatter; management targets 'half a trillion' sales pace as peers surrendered gains, China demand faces scrutiny.
White House drafting executive order to preempt state AI laws by tying federal funds to compliance, aiming for unified national standards.
OpenAI taps Foxconn to manufacture U.S.-made data center hardware, signaling AI supply chain onshoring.
U.S. proposes expansive offshore oil drilling off California and Alaska, boosting future production and sparking environmental pushback.
U.S. charges four in plot to export restricted Nvidia AI chips to China and Hong Kong, underscoring tightening tech controls.
Japan’s exports beat forecasts and core inflation hit a three-month high, strengthening the case for Bank of Japan rate hikes.
Existing home sales edged up in October, but declining inventory signals renewed housing supply constraints.
GE Appliances shifting production to U.S. could lift domestic suppliers and manufacturing employment.
Quantum computers simulated physics too complex for supercomputers, marking tangible progress toward practical quantum advantage.
Scientists grew functional miniature human blood factories, advancing prospects for lab-made transfusions and hematological therapies.
Blue Origin revealed a super-heavy New Glenn variant taller than Saturn V, intensifying competition in heavy-lift launch.
